SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: The details about the setting are important to the story because they

A.Choice: explain why the Overtons arrive so quickly

B.Choice: explain why the bat is able to enter the house

C.Choice: show why the family is looking for excitement

D.Choice: why Betsy sees the bat before anyone else

SubTopics: Recognize and explain the meaning of common idioms, adages, and proverbs.
Content: The phrase “couldn't get a word in edgewise” in paragraph 10 shows that

A.Choice: Andrew was taking a long time to finish talking

B.Choice: Andrew's family doubted what he was saying

C.Choice: Andrew's family did not know he had joined them

D.Choice: Andrew was not given the opportunity to talk

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: How do paragraphs 14 through 16 show a change in the story?

B.Choice: The action centers around the bat.

C.Choice: The action moves inside the house.

D.Choice: The characters admit they are panicking.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: In paragraph 17, Andrew turns the lights off in the house because he

A.Choice: knows the bat is used to being in the dark

B.Choice: is worried that the bat may be dangerous

C.Choice: does not want the men to attack the bat

D.Choice: does not want his family to see the bat

SubTopics: Use context (e.g., definitions, examples, or restatements in text) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.
Content: Which phrase from paragraph 17 helps readers understand the meaning of “illuminated” in paragraph 19?

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: Which sentence would be best to include in a summary of the story?

A.Choice: Mr. Overton and Mr. Halvorsen have a plan, but Andrew objects.

B.Choice: Because of Andrew, the bat is able to fly off into the night.

C.Choice: Mr. Overton praises Andrew for his smart thinking.

D.Choice: Andrew asks everyone to wait quietly.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: According to the authors, why should readers who want to mountain bike ask questions?

A.Choice: to figure out if they can do mountain biking tricks

B.Choice: to figure out if they are ready for mountain biking

C.Choice: to learn where they are allowed to ride their bikes

D.Choice: to make sure they choose the right type of bike

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: How does the information in paragraphs 4 and 5 support a main idea of the article?

A.Choice: by explaining how to prepare for mountain biking

B.Choice: by giving details about the difficulty of mountain biking

C.Choice: by showing how mountain biking can be painful

D.Choice: by describing what muscles are used in mountain biking

SubTopics: Use context (e.g., definitions, examples, or restatements in text) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 6.
:box:Broadslides, bunny-hops, and jumps will also be a part of your arsenal as you attack a biking trail.
What does “arsenal” refer to in this sentence?

SubTopics: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.
Content: According to the “Competition” section of the article, why do some mountain biking events need to be watched closely?

A.Choice: to keep track of riders' times

B.Choice: to keep track of riders' mistakes

C.Choice: to make sure riders wear helmets

D.Choice: to make sure riders are staying safe

SubTopics: Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: According to the authors, how will training, learning about bike equipment, and wearing helmets and pads help riders?

A.Choice: Riders will be prepared to safely enjoy mountain biking.

B.Choice: Riders will win mountain biking competitions.

C.Choice: Riders will not get stiff and sore after biking.

D.Choice: Riders will not get lost while biking.

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which sentence from the text best summarizes a main idea of the article?

A.Choice: “Check with friends who already take part in the sport.” (paragraph 4)

B.Choice: “Ask questions at bike stores, but remember, they want to sell you a bike, so think carefully about what they tell you.” (paragraph 5)

C.Choice: “Maneuvering your bike on off-road trails calls for skills not usually used around your neighborhood.” (paragraph 6)

D.Choice: “The winner is the first to make it through a tough course filled with obstacles like sharp turns, logs, rocks, streams, and jumps.” (paragraph 11)

SubTopics: Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: Which information most contributes to the organization of paragraph 1?

A.Choice: the comparison to the toys of today

B.Choice: the explanation of the problem of transportation

C.Choice: the mention of the cause for only a few trips to town

D.Choice: the use of words and numbers that indicate periods of time

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text.
Content: Which sentence gives the best evidence that readers can relate the article to their own lives?

A.Choice: “Town stores featured candy, jump ropes, marbles, books that were designed to teach children good behavior, china and paper dolls.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “Without store-bought toys, pioneer children made their own fun out of what they had.” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “Some of the games they played have been memorized and handed down from generation to generation and are still played today, like hopscotch, jump rope, hide and seek, and 'Mother, May I?' ” (paragraph 4)

D.Choice: “Step back in time and try your hand at making these toys from over 100 years ago.” (paragraph 5)

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which sentence best supports a main idea of the article?

A.Choice: “For pioneer children growing up in the 1800s, the nearest town could be days away by horseback or covered wagon.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “Most pioneer families had little money for fun and games.” (paragraph 2)

C.Choice: “Without store-bought toys, pioneer children made their own fun out of what they had.” (paragraph 3)

D.Choice: “Today, pioneer crafts and games are just as much fun.” (paragraph 5)

SubTopics: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.
Content: In the “Whirligig” instructions, which step relates to positioning an object?

A.Choice: nails will not puncture the hard surface created by the ice inside

D.Choice: it allows the lantern maker to avoid scratching the surface of the can

Content: In “[Excerpt from] Hattie Big Sky” and “[Excerpt from] If Wishes Were Horses,” both Hattie and Aunt Nell accept challenges that benefit them in some way. What challenges do Hattie and Aunt Nell accept? How do the stories show the benefits of accepting these challenges? Use details from both stories to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to

• describe the challenges that Hattie and Aunt Nell accept
• explain the benefits of accepting these challenges in both stories
• use details from both stories to support your response
